summary: Stack overflow crash on Windows x86 with .NET 8/9 due to missing Cdecl calling convention on LibraryImport P/Invoke declarations

stepsToReproduce: Create a .NET 8 or .NET 9 project referencing SkiaSharp 3.116+
Call any SkiaSharp API that P/Invokes into the native library (e.g., SKBitmap.GetPixel)

versionAnalysis.relevanceReason: The code generator (Generator.cs line 546) still emits [LibraryImport] without Cdecl calling convention. The generated file SkiaApi.generated.cs still lacks the necessary [UnmanagedCallConv] attribute. The bug is present on the main branch.

regression.reason: SkiaSharp 2.88.x used DllImport with CallingConvention.Cdecl exclusively. SkiaSharp 3.x introduced LibraryImport for .NET 7+ but omitted the Cdecl calling convention. On x64 this is invisible (one calling convention), on x86 it causes stack corruption.

analysis.summary: The P/Invoke code generator emits [LibraryImport(SKIA)] without specifying a calling convention. On .NET 7+ x86 Windows, LibraryImport defaults to CallingConvention.Winapi which resolves to StdCall. The native C API functions use Cdecl (the C default). This calling convention mismatch causes stack corruption on x86, manifesting as a stack overflow. On x64, there is only one calling convention, so the mismatch is invisible.
analysis.rationale: Both reporters describe x86-only crashes with .NET 8/9 that work fine on x64. The second reporter provides a clear stack overflow trace at sk_bitmap_get_pixel_color. Code investigation confirms the generated [LibraryImport] declarations lack Cdecl specification while the [DllImport] fallback correctly specifies it. The native SK_C_API macro contains no calling convention specifier, defaulting to Cdecl. This is clearly a code-generation bug, not a usage issue. Severity is critical because ALL P/Invoke calls on x86 .NET 7+ are affected — the library is fundamentally broken on this platform.

keySignals.interpretation: Classic calling convention mismatch symptom — only matters on x86 where StdCall and Cdecl differ.
Stack corruption from calling convention mismatch causes stack overflow at the P/Invoke boundary.

keySignals.text: x86 + net472: working, x86 + Net8.0: ISSUE
keySignals.interpretation: .NET Framework uses USE_DELEGATES path with correct Cdecl convention; .NET 8 uses USE_LIBRARY_IMPORT path missing Cdecl.
SkiaSharp 2.88.x didn't have LibraryImport — used DllImport with CallingConvention.Cdecl only.

keySignals.text: [LibraryImport(SKIA)] without calling convention in generated code
keySignals.interpretation: Root cause — generator emits LibraryImport without Cdecl, defaulting to StdCall on x86 Windows.

codeInvestigation.finding: [LibraryImport(SKIA)] at line 1647 does not specify calling convention. The [DllImport] fallback at line 1650 correctly specifies CallingConvention.Cdecl. This pattern repeats for ALL P/Invoke declarations in the file.

Line 546 emits `[LibraryImport ({config.DllName})]` without calling convention. Line 552 emits `[DllImport ({config.DllName}, CallingConvention = CallingConvention.Cdecl)]`. The LibraryImport path should also specify Cdecl via [UnmanagedCallConv(CallConvs = new[] { typeof(CallConvCdecl) })].
USE_DELEGATES is defined for net4x (Framework), USE_LIBRARY_IMPORT for net7.0+. This confirms .NET Framework uses correct Cdecl delegates while .NET 7+ uses the broken LibraryImport path.
SK_C_API macro only specifies dllexport/dllimport visibility, NOT a calling convention. Native functions default to __cdecl (C default on Windows).
sk_bitmap_get_pixel_color is a plain C function with no explicit calling convention — uses default __cdecl.

workarounds: Target x64 instead of x86 (x64 has a single calling convention, so the bug is invisible)
Downgrade to SkiaSharp 2.88.x which uses DllImport with correct Cdecl convention
nextQuestions: Confirm that adding [UnmanagedCallConv(CallConvs = new[] { typeof(CallConvCdecl) })] to the generator output fixes x86 .NET 8/9
Check if HarfBuzzSharp has the same LibraryImport calling convention issue

actions.comment:
Thanks for the detailed stack trace — that confirmed this.

The root cause is a calling convention mismatch in the P/Invoke bindings. SkiaSharp 3.x uses `[LibraryImport]` for .NET 7+, but the generated declarations don't specify `Cdecl` calling convention. On x86 Windows, `LibraryImport` defaults to `StdCall`, while the native C API uses `Cdecl`. This stack corruption manifests as a stack overflow. On x64 there's only one calling convention, which is why it works there. On .NET Framework, SkiaSharp uses a different code path (`DllImport`) that correctly specifies `Cdecl`.

Workaround: target x64 instead of x86 if possible — the calling convention mismatch is invisible on x64.

The fix is to update the code generator to emit `[UnmanagedCallConv(CallConvs = new[] { typeof(CallConvCdecl) })]` alongside the `[LibraryImport]` attribute.
